awd_titl_txt: HSI Planning Project: Development of an Early Attrition Predictive Model for STEM Majors at a Major Hispanic-Serving Institution
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions (HSI Program), this Track 1: PPP proposal aims to undertake an institutional-wide assessment of early STEM attrition to inform the development of a predictive model that will identify students in STEM majors who are at risk of leaving STEM or dropping out entirely, and group these students according to their risk factors. Recognizing that deficit-oriented models fail to fully explain the high-level of attrition of Hispanics and other underrepresented minorities from STEM majors, the proposed model will use both institutional data (e.g., student demographics, socioeconomic status, pre-college characteristics, enrollment patterns, academic performance, and institutional factors) and results of validated surveys administered to students and alumni who have attrited from a STEM major to identify risk factors that can be addressed institutionally. Doing so will allow the development of targeted interventions that mitigate the risk factors identified by the model in a future Track 2 submission, which will be designed to provide students with the tools and resources that will help ensure their retention and successful completion of a STEM major and entry into a post-graduate STEM career.

The aims of this proposal are to (1) work with key institutional data repositories to gather student metrics and (2) administer surveys to students from cohorts who have left the major to understand their reasons for leaving the STEM majors at John Jay College to (3) develop and validate a predictive model to identify whether patterns of attrition and factors related to attrition differ across subgroups of students.  The PI team hypothesizes that different factors will affect attrition of different students, and that these factors can be predicted and mitigated with intervention (e.g. tutoring, social support, remediation, financial counseling, etc.). The final aim is to (4) work with the major offices associated with undergraduate completion, a trained psychologist, and an independent evaluator to develop a cohort of interventions and a plan for rigorous evaluation of these interventions for submission as a future NSF HSI program Track 2 proposal. The knowledge generated in this proposal will be published in peer-reviewed literature and shared with other minority- and Hispanic-serving institutions that wish to address attrition rates of STEM majors. The model itself will be shared with other HSIs to allow them to analyze the factors affecting attrition at their institutions. The NSF HSI Program aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education, broaden participation in STEM, and build capacity at HSIs. Achieving these aims, given the diverse nature and context of HSIs, requires innovative approaches that incentivize institutional and community transformation and promote fundamental research (i) on engaged student learning, (ii) about what it takes to diversify and increase participation in STEM effectively, and (iii) that improves our understanding of how to build institutional capacity at HSIs. Projects supported by the HSI Program will draw from these approaches to generate new knowledge on how to achieve these aims.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.inst_name: CUNY John Jay College of Criminal Justice
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: CUNY John Jay College of Criminal Justice

por.por_cntn:
This project had three key goals aimed at understanding the attrition of underrepresented students from STEM majors at John Jay College, a major Hispanic- and Minority-Serving Institution in the northeastern United States.

Specifically, we aimed to:

I. Collect pre- and post-admission characteristics that may be correlated with which students succeed or attrite from our STEM majors, including which students attrite from the college.

II. Survey students who persist and leave the majors to better understand why they leave, what factors affect their experience in the major, and which interventions might prove useful in retaining them.

III. Develop a predictive model based on I and II to determine risk of attrition.

In collaboration with our Office of Institutional Research, we gathered admissions and enrollment data on three cohorts of incoming freshmen STEM majors (N=321 science, N=442 computer science). Administrative variables collected included student demographics (e.g., race/ethnicity, gender), socioeconomic status (e.g., Pell grant eligibility, household income), precollege characteristics (e.g., high school GPA), enrollment characteristics (e.g., declared major, course registration), and academic performance (e.g., overall GPA, grades earned in foundational STEM courses).

To better understanding the underlying causes of attrition, we adapted two validated surveys. We employed the First-Year Attrition Survey [Johnson & Niemi 2015] in which respondents ranked the reasons that influenced their decision to change their major or leave the institution altogether (e.g., difficulty with coursework, financial difficulty, uncertainty about future career prospects). We also modified a questionnaire based on Survey-in-a-Box: Student Experience of the Major Survey [National Center for Women & Information Technology] to delve further into other individual and institutional factors across numerous dimensions associated with retention, including classroom climate, extracurricular involvement, advisement and mentorship, and commitment and belonging. Survey data was collected (N=67 science, N=67 computer science). Logistic regression models were employed to estimate the odds of attrition during the first 5 semesters at the college. Odds-ratio models and model selection were used to assess the predictors of attrition. For additional insight into individual experiences, qualitative interviews were conducted with a subset of respondents (N=14 science, N=24 computer science).

For science majors, we found that half of the students attrited within the first two years of enrollment, with 40% of attrition occurring after the first two semesters. First semester chemistry grade was the strongest predictor of attrition five semesters after baseline and was associated with a 5-fold increased odds of attrition. Survey data showed that negative expectations and low confidence were each associated with an approximately 4-fold increased odds of low first semester chemistry performance. Classroom climate, what students described as being comfortable or uncomfortable, was strongly linked with perceptions of the quality of instruction, motivation to seek support, and their own prospects for success in the course. Students also expressed challenges and accomplishments associated with transitioning to the university environment such as shifts in responsibility, gaining institutional knowledge, and managing a variety of communications about available resources.

For computer science majors, performance in the first computer science course strongly predicted odds of attrition, and students that earned lower than a B- had an increased likelihood of attrition over time. Both low SAT Math scores and low household income predicted performance in this foundational computer science course. Survey responses highlighted significant barriers and challenges, with 35% of all respondents having considered leaving the major at some point. Those who left largely cited the difficulty of coursework, particularly in math. The most frequently mentioned obstacles in coursework included inadequate math preparation and limited access to academic assistance, which were compounded in difficult courses like the first computer science course. A strong pattern emerged wherein positive experiences came from students' participation in programs that are outside of the activities of the academic department. Students acquired mentorship, sense of belonging, peer networks, and professional development opportunities largely via extracurricular programming, rather than in the classroom.

Our institutional-specific information-based approach to an intervention may lead to higher STEM graduation rates of underrepresented students at John Jay College and increased entry into STEM-related careers post-graduation. The intellectual merit of this study is its grounding in the current literature around retention and a novel approach to modeling risk of attrition which considers the prediction of attrition, time to attrition, and the individual and institutional factors associated with attrition. This approach sheds light on the "who", "when", and "why" of attrition, and to what extent the predictive factors differ by sub-population (e.g., Hispanic women, Black men). It has the potential to identify students at high-risk of attrition at various stages of their studies (e.g., first 3 semesters vs. after the first 3 semesters). Findings from this study are being used to develop a series of interventions aimed at improving student retention and success in STEM majors, particularly for low-income and underrepresented students at HSIs and MSIs, with potential for broader application at similar institutions nationwide.


Last Modified: 12/30/2024
Modified by: Anthony Carpi
